source.title: What I Believe
source.description: Along with Why I Am Not a Christian, this essay must rank as the most articulate example of Russell's famed atheism. It is also one of the most notorious. Used as evidence in a 1940 court case in which Russell was declared unfit to teach college-level philosophy, What I Believewas to become one of his most defining works. The ideas contained within were and are controversial, contentious and - to the religious - downright blasphemous. A remarkable work, it remains the best concise introduction to Russell's....

raw.author: Socrates
contexts: Russell agreed with Mill that Socrates dissatisfied is a better man than the fool satisfied.
commentaries: The author cites Socrates as a philosophical reference point for valuing intellectual and moral integrity over mere pleasure, via Mill's formulation.

raw.title: History of Western Philosophy
raw.author: Bertrand Russell
contexts: In the middle 1950s, his History of Western Philosophy was a treat to teenage schoolboys bored to death with the slog of O Level.
commentaries: The author recalls Russell's History of Western Philosophy as an influential and accessible work that shaped young readers' views on philosophy and religion.

goodreads_match.title: History of Western Philosophy
goodreads_match.description: First published in 1946, History of Western Philosophywent on to become the best-selling philosophy book of the twentieth century. A dazzlingly ambitious project, it remains unchallenged to this day as the ultimate introduction to Western philosophy. Providing a sophisticated overview of the ideas that have perplexed people from time immemorial, it is 'long on wit, intelligence and curmudgeonly scepticism', as the New York Timesnoted, and it is this, coupled with the sheer brilliance of its scholarship, tha...

raw.author: Freud
contexts: Rivers thought Freud exaggerated his insights, but had no doubt that we are all much more at the mercy of hidden impulses than we like to think. So did Russell. In particular, Russell came close to believing that human beings were instinctively impelled to destruction for its own sake, something that Freud’s account of the ‘death wish’ also suggests.
commentaries: The author references Freud's concept of the 'death wish' as a psychological framework Russell adopted to explain human destructive impulses.

raw.author: Rousseau
contexts: Rousseau is, of course, the great protagonist of this view in Europe.
Rousseau has got used to these things, and does not regard them as against nature.
commentaries: The author cites Rousseau as the principal historical advocate of the view that opposes the 'unnatural' application of science to human life.
The author uses Rousseau as an example of someone whose conception of 'nature' is shaped by personal experience and historical context, without citing a specific work.

raw.author: John Dewey
contexts: he accused the American pragmatist John Dewey of ‘impiety’ in suggesting that nature was somehow infused with human purpose.
commentaries: The author cites Dewey as a thinker whose views on nature Russell criticized, using this to illustrate Russell's rejection of anthropocentric interpretations of nature.

raw.title: Brave New World
raw.author: Huxley
contexts: or be turned into the docile creatures imagined in Huxley’s Brave New World - a book that was probably inspired by Russell’s Icarus — genetically engineered to fit into our social roles, and fed drugs that would achieve whatever eugenics had not.
commentaries: The author references Huxley’s novel as a dystopian vision potentially inspired by Russell’s Icarus, illustrating fears of technological control and dehumanization.

goodreads_match.title: Brave New World
goodreads_match.description: Huxley's bleak future prophesized in Brave New World was a capitalist civilization which had been reconstituted through scientific and psychological engineering, a world in which people are genetically designed to be passive and useful to the ruling class. Satirical and disturbing, Brave New World is set some 600 years ahead, in "this year of stability, A.F. 632"--the A.F. standing for After Ford, meaning the godlike Henry Ford. "Community, Identity, Stability," is the motto. Reproduction is controlled thro...

raw.title: The Republic
raw.author: Plato
contexts: What I mean may become plain by comparison with Plato's Republic.
commentaries: The author invokes Plato's Republic as a conceptual contrast to illustrate the individualistic focus of Christian morality, suggesting it offers a more socially oriented vision of the good life.

goodreads_match.title: The Republic
goodreads_match.description:
Plato's most famous work and the bedrock of Western philosophy
Written in the form of a Socratic dialogue, The Republic is an investigation into the nature of an ideal society. In this far-reaching and profoundly influential treatise, Plato explores the concept of justice, the connection between politics and psychology, the difference between words and what they represent, and the roles of art and education, among many other topics. A towering achievement of philosophical insight, The Republic is as relevan...

contexts: David Copperfield and Oliver Twist are by no means imaginary.
commentaries: The author references David Copperfield as a literary example of childhood cruelty, implying the character illustrates real societal patterns.

raw.author: Bentham
contexts: Bentham supposed that the whole of morality could be derived from ‘enlightened self-interest’, and that a person who always acted with a view to his own maximum satisfaction in the long run would always act rightly.
commentaries: The author cites Bentham's utilitarian theory of morality as a position he rejects, noting that it fails to account for moral actions beyond self-interest.

raw.title: Daedalus
raw.author: Haldane
contexts: J. B. S. Haldane’s Daedalus, had offered an optimistic view of what science would do for humanity in the future; Russell riposted with Icarus, to point out that Daedalus’s son learned how to fly, but not how to fly intelligently.
commentaries: The author presents Haldane’s Daedalus as a counterpoint to Russell’s Icarus, framing it as an optimistic vision of science that Russell deliberately challenged.

goodreads_match.title_without_series: Daedalus, Or, Science and the Future
goodreads_match.title: Daedalus, Or, Science and the Future
goodreads_match.description:
Daedalus; or, Science and the Future is a book by the British scientist J. B. S. Haldane, published in England in 1924. It was the text of a lecture read to the Heretics Society, an intellectual club at Cambridge University on 4 February 1923.
Haldane uses the Greek myth of Daedalus as a symbol for the revolutionary nature of science with particular regard to his own discipline of biology.
"The chemical or physical inventor is always a Prometheus. There is no great invention, from fire to flying, which has....

raw.author: Hume
contexts: Or, as Hume put it with the sharpness that Russell relished, ‘reason is and ought to be the slave of the passions’.
commentaries: The author cites Hume's formulation to illustrate Russell's empiricist view of reason as subordinate to desire.

raw.title: Why I am not a Christian
raw.author: Bertrand Russell
contexts: Why I am not a Christian was an even more valuable weapon against authority.
commentaries: The author cites Why I am not a Christian as a key text Russell used to challenge religious authority, particularly among young readers.

goodreads_match.title_without_series: Why I Am Not a Christian
goodreads_match.title: Why I Am Not a Christian
goodreads_match.description:
While its tone is playful and frivolous, this book poses tough questions over the nature of religion and belief.
Religion provides comfortable responses to the questions that have always beset humankind - why are we here, what is the point of being alive, how ought we to behave? Russell snatches that comfort away, leaving us instead with other, more troublesome alternatives: responsibility, autonomy, self-awareness. He tells us that the time to live is now, the place to live is here, and the way to be happy...

raw.title: The Principles of Social Reconstruction
raw.author: Bertrand Russell
contexts: Much that is taken for granted in What I Believe is argued for at some length in The Principles of Social Reconstruction.

He was deeply opposed to the war and, as a member of the Union for Democratic Control early in the war and later as a leading figure in the No-Conscription Fellowship, he worked unceasingly to bring the war to an early end... Russell gave a strikingly successful series of lectures on The Principles of Social Reconstruction.
commentaries: The author identifies The Principles of Social Reconstruction as the foundational text from which key ideas in What I Believe are derived.
The author notes that Russell's lectures on The Principles of Social Reconstruction formed the basis of his political philosophy, linking them directly to his activism.

goodreads_match.title: Principles of Social Reconstruction
goodreads_match.description: This book, originally entitled Why Men Fight, is generally seen as the fullest expression of Russell's political philosophy. Russell argues that after the experience of the Great War the individualistic approach of traditional liberalism had reached its limits. Political theory must be based on the motivating forces of creativity and impulse, rather than on competition. Both are best fostered in the family, in education, and in religion - each of which Russell proceeds to discuss. The ideas expressed in Pri...

raw.author: Plato
contexts: To please these moralists, a life of torture is inflicted upon millions of human beings who ought never to have existed, merely because it is supposed that sexual intercourse is wicked unless accompanied by desire for offspring, but not wicked when this desire is present, even though the offspring is humanly certain to be wretched.
When Plato wanted to describe the good life, he described a whole community, not an individual; he did so in order to define justice, which is an essentially social conception.
commentaries: The author implicitly contrasts contemporary moral dogma with ancient philosophical traditions, suggesting that Plato’s views on reproduction and ethics are being misapplied or ignored in modern religious morality.
The author cites Plato as a foundational thinker who linked the good life to social justice, using his political philosophy to contrast individualistic moral frameworks.

raw.author: John Stuart Mill
contexts: In those ways, he was less admirable than John Stuart Mill.
commentaries: The author contrasts Russell's critical practice with Mill's, citing Mill as a more admirable exemplar of intellectual fairness.

raw.author: Savonarola
contexts: the influence of revivalists, from Savonarola downwards, has always been very transitory.
commentaries: The author cites Savonarola as a historical example of a moralist whose influence through exhortation was temporary.

raw.title: Icarus
raw.author: Bertrand Russell
contexts: In Icarus I expressed my fears; in the following pages I have expressed my hopes.
Russell riposted with Icarus, to point out that Daedalus’s son learned how to fly, but not how to fly intelligently.
commentaries: The author references Russell's book Icarus as a counterpart to What I Believe, highlighting Russell's dual perspective on humanity's use of science.
The author cites Russell’s own pamphlet Icarus as a pessimistic rebuttal to technological optimism, warning of science’s potential for destruction.

raw.author: Ahmes
contexts: Perhaps in the times of Ahmes the multiplication table was exciting.
commentaries: The author invokes Ahmes as a historical reference point to contrast the perceived excitement of early mathematical discovery with the perceived dullness of completed physical science.

raw.author: Shelley
contexts: Shelley’s poems afford an illustration of this conception applied to societies; the moment comes when everybody is converted, the ‘anarchs’ fly, and ‘the world’s great age begins anew’.
commentaries: The author references Shelley’s poetry as a literary embodiment of the Christian-inspired belief in sudden, catastrophic societal transformation toward salvation.
